anchor.surface_text: The facts leading thereto are as follows. One Ramani Kanta Roy was possessed of companysiderable properties.

issues.text: Whether there is an executable decree which can form the subject-matter of execution under the compromise petition?

anchor.surface_text: Before considering the objection raised under point No. 1, it is right to mention that a minor objection has been taken that, as a fact, there is no executable decree which can form the subject-matter of execution. It is pointed out that cl.  c  of the compromise petition is to the effect that defendant No. 1  the present respondent No. 1  will be entitled to realise the amount in default by means of execution of the decree to be passed in terms of this petition of compromise but that there is noformal decree carrying this out and directing that the plaintiffs therein, Rajes and Ramendra, do pay to the first defendant therein, Santi Debi, the sum of Rs. 475 per month.

issues.text: Whether, under the compromise decree, as a matter of construction, the personal remedy can be pursued only after the remedy by way of charge is exhausted?

anchor.surface_text: 1  Under the compromise decree which is number sought to be put in execution, charge was created over certain properties for the due payment of the monthly allowance and hence as a matter of construction of the decree, the personal remedy can be pursued only after the remedy by way of charge is exhausted,

issues.text: Whether, on a true construction of the terms of the trust deed, the interest of the judgment-debtor, Rajes, in the properties covered by the trust deed is vested or contingent and hence attachable?

anchor.surface_text: on a true construction of the terms of. the trust deed the interest of the judgment-debtor, Rajes,  1  in the properties covered by the trust deed, and  2  in particular, in property No. 44/2, Lansdowne Road sought to be attached, is only a contingent one and hence number attachable.

issues.text: Whether the interest of Rajes in premises No. 44/2, Lansdowne Road under the trust deed is contingent due to the obligation to provide alternative accommodation?

anchor.surface_text: The further question that arises is whether in view of the terms to be numbericed, his interest in No. 44/2, Lansdowne Road, against which execution is sought is in any way different.

holdings.text: There is an executable decree; the minor objection that there is no formal decree directing payment is overruled.

anchor.surface_text: We do not think that in this case the execution is to be defeated on this ground. There is no indication in the judgment either of the Subordinate Judge or of the High Court that any such point has been raised before them. We accordingly overrule this objection.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Decree in Bengal practice incorporates solenama as part of decree, implying payment direction; no such point raised below.

holdings.text: Under the compromise decree, personal remedy is available without first exhausting the charged properties.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, of the opinion that the contention raised to the effect that the personal remedy is not available in this case before exhausting the charged properties, is not sustainable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Clauses c, d, e read harmoniously: cl. c gives unqualified personal right to execute; d and e provide optional remedies via charge or receiver without limiting personal remedy.

holdings.text: Rajes' interest in lots I to IV under the trust deed is vested, not contingent, and attachable.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, of the opinion that in so far as the interest of Rajes is concerned in lots I to IV under the trust deed, it is vested and not contingent.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Comprehensive construction of trust deed shows intention for vested interest: bias favors vesting; income applied for benefit including debts (sons liable as heirs); devolves to heirs; guided by TPA ss.19,21; Succession Act ss.119,120; Dayabhaga law.

holdings.text: Rajes' interest in premises No. 44/2, Lansdowne Road under the trust deed is vested (title vested, enjoyment restricted), not contingent, and attachable.

anchor.surface_text: It appears to us reasonably clear that the intention of the settlor, taking cls. 12 a and c together, is that as regards Lots I to IV, the beneficial interest of Rajes as regards all the properties comprised therein, including premises No. 44/2, Lansdowne Road, is vested in title but restricted in enjoyment

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cl.12 a and c: vesting immediate upon trust end (debts paid, settlor death); obligation for alternative house affects only enjoyment/residence right of Ramendra, not vesting; no extra contingency.

holdings.text: Objections to execution untenable: personal remedy available; Rajes' interest under trust vested and attachable.

anchor.surface_text: We are clearly of the opinion that the objection raised to the execution 1 on the ground that the properties charged are to be proceeded against, in the first instance, and 2 on the ground that the interest which Rajes gets under the trust deed either as regards the general properties covered by the deed or as regards premises No. 44/2, Lansdowne Road, is contingent, are untenable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Summarizes holdings on both main issues, dismissing appeal.

holdings.text: Mere contingent interest, though transferable inter vivos, is not attachable in execution.

anchor.surface_text: That a mere contingent interest though transferable inter vivos is not attachable is well settled since the Privy Council decision in Pestonjee Bhicajee v. P. H. Anderson.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Accepted as settled law from Privy Council precedent; distinguished as Rajes' interest vested.

anchor.surface_text: not attachable is well settled since the Privy Council decision in Pestonjee Bhicajee v. P. H. Anderson  1 . The question as to whether the interest of the judgment-debtor, Rajes, in this case is vested or contingent, is one not altogether free from difficulty. But it is well to notice at the outset that this point has not been raised in the petition filed by the judgment-debtor, Rajes, under s. 47 of the Code of Civil Procedure.

anchor.surface_text: that such beneficial interest would be attachable provided it is a I.L.R. 1939 Bom. 36. vested interest and not a contingent interest. The judgment of the executing court, however, shows that what was dealt with there is the contention that the interest under the trust deed was a mere expectancy as opposed to a vested interest. The Court held that the interest which the judgment-debtors had in the property by virtue of the deed of trust was not a mere expectancy.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges of the High Court relied on illustration  v  to s. 119 of the Indian Succession Act and the decision in Ranganatha Mudaliar v. A. Mohana Krishna Mudaliar  1 . The learned Solicitor General appearing for the appellant before us has urged that there is no such inflexible rule of law as is assumed by the High Court, viz., that in spite of a clause requiring payment of debts before the property reaches the hands of the donee, the gift is a vested one.

Mountague 2  in which it was held, on a construction of the terms of the trust, that the payment of the debts was a condition precedent to the vesting of the interest devised therein.
